DataElement.preferredName: Histology WHO Classification of Tumors Low Grade Glioma Yes No Not Applicable Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A yes/no/not applicable indicator for whether the histologies are tumors considered LGG or low-grade astrocytoma by WHO classification of CNS tumors

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Histology WHO Classification of Tumors Low Grade Glioma
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains._A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings._A grade I or grade II glioma arising from the central nervous system. This category includes pilocytic astrocytoma, diffuse astrocytoma, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, oligoastrocytoma, and angiocentric glioma.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Property.preferredName: WHO Classification of Tumors Low Grade Glioma
Property.preferredDefinition: A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings.:A grade I or grade II glioma arising from the central nervous system. This category includes pilocytic astrocytoma, diffuse astrocytoma, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, oligoastrocytoma, and angiocentric glioma.

Concepts.definition: A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings.

A grade I or grade II glioma arising from the central nervous system. This category includes pilocytic astrocytoma, diffuse astrocytoma, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, oligoastrocytoma, and angiocentric glioma.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.changeDescription: 10.2.20 TL changed WFS from RETIRED PHASED OUT to RETIRED ARCHIVED. Retired DBW 04-27-2016 per Tina Taylor approved by Dianne Reves

ValueDomain.changeDescription: 3/12/17 jk added Standard reg status; ownership transfered from CTEP to NCI Standards with concurrence of CTEP/Brian Campbell. 8/3/2015 Corrections made to VD in order to restore to original format: removed C49486 as rep term and replaced with C49797; restored long name and definition per Dianne Reeves/tt.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Do histologies include tumors
ReferenceDocuments.description: Do histologies include tumors considered LGG or low-grade astrocytoma (WHO Grade I and II) by 5th edition WHO classification of CNS tumors with the exception of subependymal giant cell astrocytoma?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 01
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is the tumor a low grade glioma or low-grade astrocytoma (WHO Grade I and II) by 5th edition WHO classification of CNS tumors (not including subependymal giant cell astrocytoma)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 02
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is the tumor a low grade glioma or low-grade astrocytoma (WHO Grade I or II) by the WHO Classification of Tumors of the CNS - 4th Edition Revised,  (not including subependymal giant cell astrocytoma)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 001
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is the tumor a low grade glioma or low-grade astrocytoma (WHO Grade I or II) by the WHO Classification of Tumors of the CNS - 5th Edition Revised,  (not including subependymal giant cell astrocytoma)?
